detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: This week, New Mexico Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham announced a proposal to make all state colleges tuition-free, including four-year colleges. The scholarship would apply to all students who are in-state residents regardless of family income, and it's being called one of the boldest plans yet to increase access to higher education. It's called The Opportunity Scholarship, and Governor Lujan Grisham is with us now to tell us more. We reached her in her offices in Santa Fe, N.M. Governor, thank you so much for speaking with us.
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: Absolutely, Michel. I'm delighted to be on the show and to talk more about this higher education initiative.

detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: Well, obviously, you've been thinking about this for a while. I want to note that your bio says, for example, as governor, Lujan Grisham has implemented a series of evidence-based policies aimed at transforming New Mexico's public education system and, you know, among other things. So what is the evidence that suggests that this is the right way to go?
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: Well, actually, thank you for asking that. There is a ton that shows that, look - if you give college students - and this is also irrespective, right? - we want returning students to also be able to participate. If you are really clear about that access, you create an economic engine and future for the state. It shows how it translates to people staying and working, creating new entrepreneur and business opportunities. And this is a state that's got all of this potential. And we have not really diversified or grown our economy in any meaningful ways. And, in fact, you know, we're losing our young people. They're looking for opportunities somewhere else. They are the future. We need them to participate right here. And this gives them the tools and resources that they have long needed to be a productive, contributing community member, and they want to.

detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: And where does the money come from? It's estimated to cost between $25 million and $35 million How does the state pay for this?
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: Well, you know, right now, our revenues are really strong, and the bulk of them are coming from oil and gas. We are estimated to be the - we're the third-largest oil and gas producer in the country. I think people, the experts believe we'll be second in the next year or so, so we know that that's not slowing up. And those revenues allow me to make these investments and grow the economy in other places. So I'm betting that the evidence that we've been reviewing and researching plays out by getting all of these students to have jobs right here that finally once and for all grow and diversify our economy. And we're also socking away some of that money into good reserves and good savings. So I'm feeling really good about that.

detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: We live in a time when - not least because this is a presidential election, but also kind of just because of the tenor of public debate in the last couple of years - we're living in a time when people are asking some very hard and intense questions about the role of government. I mean, some people - as we know, during the course of the presidential campaign, many people are saying that there are a lot of things in this - the way our government is ordered that need to be reoriented. And other people are saying, absolutely not. In fact, some people are decrying proposals like this as socialist and are not in keeping with American traditions, while other people are saying this is absolutely common sense, and this is what a modern economy needs. What kind of reaction are you getting in New Mexico to this?
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: We're, getting a really strong positive reaction. And I'll tell you why I think that's so. A, we have real education challenges. And New Mexicans and New Mexico families want a whole different dynamic. They want to lead in that space. They want to change their outcomes. They want to close those achievement gaps. So we're getting support to invest from early childhood education all the way to higher education. And people here - and they're right. I agree with them. I agree with my constituents, who I work for, that we need a robust, comprehensive effort. And I certainly don't think that we'll have every single Democrat and every single Republican member of the legislature vote for this proposal. But I'm not expecting to have a tough time getting it passed. But New Mexico is in a unique position. Our fiscal house is in order. We're saving money. We do have an oil and gas boom. We're trying to be very smart about that, and we're investing in places where we know it makes a real difference. We are making sure that we're laying those foundations so that it's not a temporary effort by us. We're going to make it last the long haul. That - I think New Mexico then will change the conversation for other states and for the nation because I have no doubt we're going to be successful.

detailed_metrics_by_round.actual_question: That is the governor of New Mexico, Michelle Lujan Grisham, talking about the New Mexico Opportunity Scholarship. It would make New Mexico the second state in the country to provide full tuition coverage to its student residents. Governor, thank you so much for talking to us. And we'll follow the debate and keep in touch.
detailed_metrics_by_round.previous_answer: Thank you, Michel. I really appreciate this opportunity.

How do you envision the Opportunity Scholarship influencing the long-term economic landscape of New Mexico, particularly in terms of workforce development and entrepreneurship?
What lessons or models from New Mexico’s Opportunity Scholarship do you hope could be adopted by other states facing similar educational and economic challenges?
How do you personally feel when you see young people in New Mexico gaining access to education through the Opportunity Scholarship?
What challenges or emotional obstacles have you faced while pushing for comprehensive education reform, and how have you overcome them?
Can you share a specific moment or story that deeply inspired you to dedicate your efforts toward education and economic opportunities in New Mexico?
What long-term goals do you have for The Opportunity Scholarship in transforming New Mexico's education and economy?
In what ways do you envision the Opportunity Scholarship initiative serving as a model for other states?
How do you plan to navigate differing opinions on the government's role in education funding to achieve support for your scholarship proposal?
Given the varying opinions on the role of government in education funding, how do you plan to engage with legislators and stakeholders who are skeptical about the Opportunity Scholarship?
What specific metrics or indicators will you use to evaluate the success of the Opportunity Scholarship over the next five years?
In what ways do you envision the Opportunity Scholarship serving as a model for other states facing similar economic and educational challenges?
If the Opportunity Scholarship were a seed planted in New Mexico's educational landscape, what kind of tree or forest would you envision growing from it in 10 or 20 years?

Imagine a future where the Opportunity Scholarship has successfully transformed New Mexico's economy and education system. What unexpected challenges and opportunities might have arisen during this transformation?

Education reform and economic growth are often discussed separately; if you had to compose a piece of music symbolizing the harmony between these two themes in New Mexico, what instruments or sounds would you choose and why?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: What specific mechanisms are in place to measure the success and impact of the Opportunity Scholarship on educational outcomes in New Mexico?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: What specific mechanisms are in place to measure the success and impact of the Opportunity Scholarship on educational outcomes in New Mexico?
Can you discuss any challenges or resistance encountered during the implementation of the Opportunity Scholarship and how those were addressed?
How do you plan to ensure the Opportunity Scholarship effectively addresses disparities in access to quality education among different communities within New Mexico?
How do you plan to build and maintain bipartisan support for the Opportunity Scholarship amidst existing legislative challenges?
Can you elaborate on how public opinion diversity on government roles in education funding influences your policy approach?
What measures are in place to ensure that the Opportunity Scholarship creates equitable access across different communities in New Mexico?
Looking ahead, how do you envision the Opportunity Scholarship evolving over the next decade to address emerging economic and educational challenges in New Mexico?
In what ways do you hope New Mexico's approach to education funding and economic development through initiatives like the Opportunity Scholarship might serve as a model for other states?
Given the importance of community engagement in your administration, how do you plan to involve diverse communities in shaping the future direction of economic and educational reforms?
How do you ensure that local communities are actively involved in shaping education policies like the Opportunity Scholarship?
Can you share examples of how feedback from New Mexico residents has influenced recent policy decisions in education or economic growth?
What strategies do you employ to support entrepreneurship and local business development as part of your broader economic growth plan?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: How do you plan to ensure that the Opportunity Scholarship reaches and benefits students from the most underserved communities in New Mexico?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: How do you plan to ensure that the Opportunity Scholarship reaches and benefits students from the most underserved communities in New Mexico?
What role do you see community engagement playing in the ongoing development and success of the Opportunity Scholarship program?
Can you share any specific strategies you have in mind to measure the long-term impact of the scholarship on both education outcomes and economic growth in the state?

Given your vision for education reform, are there other complementary policies or initiatives you are pursuing alongside the Opportunity Scholarship to further support students and workforce development?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: Governor Lujan Grisham, can you elaborate on the specific long-term goals you have for the Opportunity Scholarship and how you envision it transforming New Mexico's education and economy over the next decade?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: Governor Lujan Grisham, can you elaborate on the specific long-term goals you have for the Opportunity Scholarship and how you envision it transforming New Mexico's education and economy over the next decade?
How do you plan to ensure that the Opportunity Scholarship effectively addresses achievement gaps among underserved communities in New Mexico?
What role do you see community engagement playing in the implementation and success of this scholarship program, and how will you involve local stakeholders?
In what ways do you think the Opportunity Scholarship could serve as a model for other states, and what advice would you give to other governors looking to implement similar initiatives?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: You mentioned that New Mexico's fiscal house is in order and that this initiative is designed to last the long haul. What specific measures are in place to ensure the sustainability of the Opportunity Scholarship program over the next decade?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: You mentioned that New Mexico's fiscal house is in order and that this initiative is designed to last the long haul. What specific measures are in place to ensure the sustainability of the Opportunity Scholarship program over the next decade?

Given the mixed political reactions nationally about the government's role in education, how do you plan to build bipartisan support within New Mexico for this scholarship and similar education reforms?
How do you envision the Opportunity Scholarship impacting workforce development in New Mexico, especially in sectors beyond oil and gas?
Looking beyond New Mexico, what advice or lessons would you share with other states considering similar full tuition scholarship programs?

selected_suggestion_metrics.question: How do you plan to ensure that the Opportunity Scholarship also addresses equity and inclusion among historically underserved communities in New Mexico?

all_suggestion_metrics.question: How do you plan to ensure that the Opportunity Scholarship also addresses equity and inclusion among historically underserved communities in New Mexico?
What measures will be put in place to track the success and impact of the scholarship on students' academic and career outcomes?
Given the reliance on oil and gas revenues, how does the state plan to sustain this scholarship program in the face of potential market fluctuations or shifts toward renewable energy?
Can you share how community engagement has shaped the design of the Opportunity Scholarship and what role local stakeholders will have moving forward?
